answer: Being a multi-planet species is more than simply life insurance for life collectively. It's also about giving life meaning.

And the universe is 13.8 billion years old and has been around for 13.8 billion light years. And the things that we call atoms and elements are just the same thing in a different form. And so, if you say, what is the smartest thing in the room? Is it the atom or is it the human being? The human being is the smartest thing in the room by far. And we’re just a tiny, tiny, tiny fraction of the age of the universe.
So there’s a lot of fundamental physics that we don’t know. And there may be things that are out there that are fundamentally dangerous to the existence of life as we know it. And we should try to understand more about the nature of the universe and the existence of life and what is the meaning of life and what is the purpose of life. answer: We focus on making the best products and Tesla has gotten to where it’s gotten with no advertising at all.
pred_1:
I think our approach to product development is very good. We really try to make products that people love. And we try to make sure that every little thing, the design of every part, is maximizing the functional aesthetic, so it has to serve a purpose and look great.
And we try to make sure that our customers love the product, that they would recommend it to their friends and family. And we try to be as transparent as possible about the product. So you can see what’s going on. And if you go to our factories, we have a factory tour where you can see exactly what’s going on. And we try to be as open as possible.
I think that’s very important. And we also try to listen to our customers and try to make the product better based on what they’re saying. So if there’s some feature that they really want, and it makes sense to add that feature, we’ll try to add that feature. And if there’s some feature that they don’t like, and it’s within our power to change that, we’ll try to change it.
pred_2:
I mean, I think it’s just being very focused on making great products that people love and that really deliver on the promises that we make. And then, you know, word of mouth is just people talking to each other. They can always, by the way, lie to each other, but they can also tell the truth. And, you know, generally, if you make something that’s high quality and people really love it, then they will tell others.
And then, also, we have a very strong presence online, you know, on Twitter, on our website, and other places online where people can just talk directly to us and ask questions. And we try to be as responsive as possible to questions that people have online. I think that’s also a big advantage.
And then, you know, we just try to make as many right decisions as possible. I mean, I think the success of a company is really the sum of all the right decisions that a company makes. And then, if you make more right decisions than wrong decisions, you’ll succeed. If you make more wrong decisions than right decisions, you’ll fail.

answer: If I were to describe my philosophy, it is a philosophy of curiosity. I did have this existential crisis when I was around 12.
pred_1: I was thinking about this quite a lot when I was 12. The reason being, I was in school, and they were teaching me about the history of the world, and it seemed to be a long series of mistakes. It seemed like people would do something, they’d make some mistake, that would lead to some war or some terrible outcome. Then the next thing would happen, they’d make another mistake. It seemed like everything was just a series of mistakes. I was trying to figure out, is there some way to break this chain of mistakes and have a better future? That really motivated me to try to think about how to make the future better.
pred_2:
I had a lot of, I guess, philosophical kind of questions. I read a lot of books on philosophy and religion. I was grounded in physics, actually, first, because I was taking apart computers and then I wanted to understand how they worked. And I built a computer when I was 12. And then I thought, well, what’s the point of a computer? What can a computer do that’s interesting? And I thought, well, let’s see, if I can make it play music, then that would be cool. And so I taught it to play Chopin’s prelude in C-sharp minor. And then I thought, well, let’s see if I can make it play better than any violinist in the world, which is about three years after that, I did. And then I thought, well, what else can I do?
And I thought, well, let’s see if I can make it play better than any orchestra in the world. And that took about two years. And then I thought, well, what else can I do? And I thought, well, let’s see if I can make it compose original music. And that was kind of interesting, but not that exciting. And then I thought, well, let’s see if I can make it do things that are not musical. And so I taught it to recognize speech and to do simple tasks like that. And then I thought, well, let’s see if I can make it do things that are impossible or that a human can’t do.

answer: These demons of the mind are, for the most part, harnessed to productive ends.
pred_1:
Well, I think I've come to understand the nature of thought and the mind and the brain to a certain degree. I mean, I'm not a neuroscientist, but I do a lot of work in neuroscience because I think it is the thing that is the foundation of the future. In order to understand the future, you must understand the brain. And the future is coming fast, so we must understand the brain fast.
I mean, I've come to the conclusion that, like, the mind is a series of thought constructs, and there are two levels of thought constructs. There's the slow, kind of, diffuse thought constructs, which are like the river of thought. And then there are the fast, kind of, pointillist thought constructs, which are like the individual blobs of color in the river of thought. And these can be edited, and they're not coherent. And when you edit these fast thought constructs, it feels like you're editing reality.
Now, this is quite disconcerting because it feels like if you can edit these fast thought constructs, which you can do, and you can edit reality, then what is reality? And so, I think, one of the things that Neuralink is trying to do is to provide a high bandwidth interface to the brain such that we can better understand these thought constructs, the nature of the mind, the brain. And I think it could also provide a means for us to be symbiotic with A.I.
pred_2: Well, I've always been interested in the future and in the limit, what an civilization looks like if it's successful and exists for a long time. And that is the definition of a civilization that I think we should strive for. A civilization that is long-lasting and where life on Earth is abundant and prosperous. And so I've been working on that for a long time. My first company was a software company called 'Zip2'. And the reason I started a software company was because I thought the internet was going to be important, and nobody in Silicon Valley seemed to think it was important. And I thought that was crazy, so I started a company to do software for the internet. And that company ended up doing very well. It got acquired by eBay. And then I used the money that I got from that to start SpaceX. And then I did an MBA at Stanford. And then I started Tesla. And so I've always been trying to push in that direction. And now we have Neuralink, which is really, I think, the most fundamental thing of all. Because an civilization that is long-lasting and where life on Earth is abundant and prosperous must be a civilization that is at least an order of magnitude smarter than we are. And so the point of Neuralink is to create a high bandwidth interface to the brain such that we can be symbiotic with A.I.  Because we have a bandwidth problem. You just can't communicate through your fingers. It's too slow.

answer: We have given a lot of attention to community notes, which corrects misinformation.
pred_1: I’m not sure how to answer that question. We do our best to be as truthful as possible.
pred_2:
We’re not trying to be a sort of policing the misinformation. The aspiration for Twitter is to be the best source of truth that’s ever existed. And so, instead of trying to police misinformation, which is a sort of… You’re sort of playing whack-a-mole, because there’s a new form of misinformation that arises every day. The best approach is to simply be the best source of truth. And if something is not true, then the best source of truth will cause it to be defeated by the marketplace.
So, we’re not trying to be sort of the arbiter of what is truth. We’re trying to be the best source of truth. And we’re also trying to elevate the good journalists and bring them closer to the people. And we’re also trying to bring the people to the journalists, so that the journalists can actually hear what the people have to say. And we’re also adding a lot of context to what’s said on Twitter, so that if somebody is replying to something, that they will see all of the replies, and they’ll see all of the conversation around something, so that they can understand what everybody else is saying about a particular thing.
And we’re also adding a lot of functionality to communities. So, if something is a sort of a niche subject, you can still find the people who are interested in that niche subject. And you can then ask them questions. And you can also ask questions of the community. So, you can say, “I’m confused about this. Can you help me understand?” And then, the community can help you understand.

I think if you do the right things for the company, the stock price will eventually reflect that.

answer: Twitter should be a town square that gives equal voice to the whole country.
pred_1: I think there’s a place for political discourse, but it can’t be where everything is censored. Then it’s not a discourse. Where you have censorship of everything, then there’s no discourse. So I think we’re just going to have to see how it evolves. I think we’re going to have to be open to what people want. And if there’s too much censorship, then people will just leave the platform.
pred_2: Well, I think we’re going to try to be as even-handed as possible. So we’re not trying to put a thumb on the scale monetarily or in any way. So I think we’re just trying to be as even-handed as possible. And like I said, the acid test is what do users think? And if users think that Twitter is a force for good, that it is a good source of truth, then they will stay on the platform and invite others to stay on the platform. And if they don’t, they will leave and they’ll take their friends and family with them. So I think the best source of truth is what users think. And we’re going to try to do our best to amplify the voice of the people.

answer: I thought Twitter would perhaps accelerate progress versus creating something from scratch by 3 to 5 years.
pred_1: I thought it was important to have a vibrant, open digital town square, and Twitter is one of the few places that is. But it’s been neglected and not run well for a long time.
pred_2:
Well, I thought the existing platform, even with all its issues, was actually quite good at getting things done. And I thought, well, there’s a lot of things that I would like to do that are not antithetical to Twitter. I think some of the things that I would like to do are actually very synergistic with Twitter. For example, adding payroll. I’m often asked, well, what’s the purpose of X in that regard. Well, one of the purposes of X is to provide a source of income for people, and a source of income for the company. And so having a payroll feature on Twitter, where you can get paid for doing things on Twitter, I think would be a great way to monetize.
It’s not like I’m strapped for cash or anything. But I think it would be a great way to monetize. It’s not some sort of a desperate move. I mean, it’s not a desperate move because I’m not desperate for money. But I think it would be a great way to monetize user activity. And generally, I’m just trying to think of what’s in the best interest of the users. And I think providing a way for people to get paid for their user activity on Twitter would be great.

answer: I have this sort of long-term vision of something called X.com from way back in the day, which is sort of like an everything app where it’s just maximally useful. It does payments, provides financial services, provides information flow, really anything digital. It also provides secure communications.
pred_1:
I think the long-term vision for Twitter is to be the de facto digital town square where people feel comfortable talking about a wide range of topics. I think we’ve made a lot of progress in that direction. There’s still a lot of work to do. But I think it’s really important to have a wide range of viewpoints expressed on Twitter, not just a narrow range of viewpoints. And that there’s a wide range of viewpoints expressed, I think that’s important to the truth.
If you only hear a narrow range of viewpoints, then you’re not really hearing the truth. I think we’ve made a lot of progress in that regard. But there’s still more work to do. And I think it’s also important to be… Twitter to be as inclusive as possible, meaning we want as many people as possible to join Twitter. And I think we’ve made a lot of progress in that regard as well. But there’s still more work to do in that regard.
pred_2:
Well, my long-term vision for Twitter is to make it the best source of truth on Earth. And we’re going to take steps to ensure that that is the case. We’re going to radically improve the quality of recommendations so that you can actually count on what Twitter recommends to you. We’re going to radically improve the relevance of the recommendations so that they’re actually relevant to you. And we’re going to radically improve the accuracy of the system.
So, we’re going to take steps to make sure that, like, if something is posted on Twitter, that it is in fact true. And if it is not true, that we add a lot of context so that users can understand what is actually going on. So, I think, it’s very important for the future of civilization that Twitter is a force for good and that it is truthful. And we’re going to do our absolute best to make it the best source of truth on Earth.

answer: We’re putting a lot of effort into something called 'Community Notes'. It’s currently just in English, but we will be expanding it to all languages. answer: Some things that we could do to make education more compelling would be to explain to children why we are teaching a particular subject. I also think that critical thinking is something that should be taught to children at a relatively young age.
pred_1:
I think you’ve got to start off with principles of ‘Why are we educating people?’ And I think it’s to enlighten the mind and to prepare people for the future. And so I think we want to make sure we’re teaching the things that are important to enlighten the mind, so that’s kind of foundational knowledge. Foundational knowledge in mathematics, foundational knowledge in language, these are the building blocks, and then everything else is kind of like, these are electives.
You can think of the school system a little bit like a pyramid. And at the base of the pyramid, everyone needs to learn these foundational skills. Everyone needs to learn basic literacy and numeracy. Everyone. Just like everyone who goes to college or university needs to learn these things. So it’s just that the pyramid is shaped such that a vast number of people do not go beyond the foundational skills.
But I think if we can make learning more engaging and more fun, then I think it’s much more likely that people will continue with their education. Because the thing is that most people are kind of the same. They’re like, they have parents, they have a family, they have friends, and they have school. And most people would say, if you ask them, like, on a scale of one to 10, how much do you like your family, how much do you like your friends, how much do you like school? It’s going to be, you know, one, two, three, four, five. And then the rest of the things will be, you know, eight, nine, 10.
So if you can make school better, which is something we should obviously try to do, then it’s more likely that people will continue with their education. And I think it’s also important to emphasize things that are not just the tools of enlightenment but also the things that are necessary for preparing people for the future. So obviously reading, writing, and arithmetic are important. But also things like, how do you fix a car? How do you cook a meal? How do you sew a button on your shirt? These kinds of things.
And I think it’s also important to teach people how to think. How to reason. How to solve problems. How to be creative. And I think it’s also important to teach people how to be kind and how to be fair. And how to have empathy for your fellow human beings. And I think it’s also important to teach people how to be happy. Because that’s what life is all about.
pred_2:
Well, I think first of all, you really need to fire the teachers that are bad. And I think there should be, like, if a teacher is not doing a good job, principally, they should fire them. And if they don’t fire them, then you should go to the school board and say, “Why aren’t you firing this teacher?” And I think we should have much higher standards for teachers. I think we should require that they get better grades in college, and that they get a degree in the subject that they’re teaching.
And I think we should have, like, if somebody’s going to be a teacher, I think they should have a mentor teacher that they work with, and they only get their full teacher certificate if their mentor teacher says that they should get it. And I think we should have, you know, like, if somebody’s a teacher, they should have to reapply for their job every year. And if they don’t reapply, then they lose their job. And I think we should rotate teachers around every few years so they don’t get complacent.
And I think we should have, you know, like, if somebody’s been a teacher for a while, and they haven’t been doing a good job, we should say, “Okay. You either go back to college and get some more training, or you’re fired.” I think we should be much more demanding of teachers, and principals, and school superintendents. And if they don’t shape up, they should lose their job.

answer: I don’t think it’s aliens, no. I do find the whole question of aliens a very interesting one, what is typically called the Fermi Paradox, which is: If the universe is really as old as science seems to think it is, where are the aliens?
pred_1: I think we should really be careful about any kind of message that we put out about UFOs or aliens because we are not the aliens. And we don’t want to give the aliens the wrong impression. They may come and eat us. Or they might just think we’re stupid. One of the two.
pred_2: Well, I think we need to be open to the possibility of new discoveries. I think we should be open to the possibility that there are many one-planet civilizations that died out millions of years ago and never made it to the second planet. We don’t want to be one of those one-planet civilizations. Let’s try to be a multi-planet civilization and be out there among the stars.

answer: I sleep six hours a night, and if I sleep less than six hours a night, I find that I might be awake longer, but I get less done.
pred_1: Well, I used to be able to function on five or six hours of sleep. But now I seem to need at least seven or eight. And if I don’t get that, I’m just not sharp. When I was younger, I could get away with it. Now I need at least seven or eight hours.
pred_2: I usually get about six hours a night and that’s been pretty consistent. I think I could probably get by on less, but I don’t find that I get by on less. Six hours is fine.

answer: I think I’d be comfortable with a mere 80-hour workweek. That would be fine. That is what I would aspire to.
pred_1:
I used to have a very intense work schedule. In fact, I had a 16-hour workday, and I would work seven days a week. And I would not even take vacations. And then I had a bit of a health issue. I burnt myself out pretty badly. And so I had to take a break and go on disability for a few months. And so I learned the hard way that you need to take care of yourself.
So now I work, I would say, a more normal, like eight-hour day, and I try to take the weekends off, and I try to take vacations. And I really think that is important for performing at a high level. If you don’t take care of yourself, you can’t take care of the company. And I really learned that lesson, I think, quite hardcore. So I really, really try to adhere to that and set a good example for taking care of yourself.
pred_2: I work a lot. I mean, I work seven days a week and put in some pretty crazy hours. I think some people don’t like that. They think, “Oh, you know, working seven days a week is bad.” I think if you’re going to make something great, that’s what it takes.

answer: I played a significant role in the creation of OpenAI. At the time I was concerned that Google was not paying enough attention to AI safety, and so I, with a number of other people, created OpenAI. I don’t have any stake in OpenAI anymore, nor am I on the Board, nor do I control it in any way.
pred_1: I helped create OpenAI, and I’m I guess you could say an advisor or on the board. I’m not sure how you’d characterize my involvement.
pred_2: I’m one of the founders of OpenAI. I helped with the creation of OpenAI. I’m on the board, but I have to say I’ve been on the board, but I haven’t been active on the board. I was just at a board meeting, though. So I’m trying to think of what are the things that OpenAI does. I guess there’s a few things. One is we have a lot of open source software. So we have a lot of just software that runs on GPU’s that’s open source. We have a lot of training on artificial intelligence on our hardware. We also have a few AI generative systems that create art, I guess is one of them.

answer: We need to regulate AI safety. I think we should have a similar sort of regulatory oversight for artificial intelligence because it is, actually, a bigger risk to society than cars or planes, or medicine.
pred_1:
I think if you drive a car, you’d like there to be some regulatory oversight on the safety of the car. If there’s a car that’s driven by humans that’s potentially going to crash and maybe kill people, you’d want there to be some regulatory oversight on the safety of that car. I think if a medical device, some sort of a medical procedure, is going to potentially affect your health or someone else’s health, you’d want there to be regulatory oversight on the safety of that medical device. So I don’t know of any industry where there isn’t regulatory oversight on the safety of the products.
I think AI is no different. AI is just a tool. We should view AI as a tool. It’s not an alien. It’s not like a sentient being. It’s a tool. And we should say, “What is the probability that this tool, if given a large amount of power, will do good or bad?” And I think the probability of it doing bad is greater than the probability of it doing good. Therefore, we should have regulatory oversight to ensure that it does not do bad.
pred_2: I think AI is a bit of a special case, and I think there is a risk if AI is not properly controlled, it could be a danger to the future of civilization. So I think there should be just a government oversight, just like there is for food and drug safety, and there is for rockets and cars. There isn’t just a haphazard HMI, or whatever, in those situations. And I think AI is a bit of a special case, and I think it is important to have some kind of regulatory oversight to ensure that the safety of civilization is not a risk.
